title: about
text:
Finley Malloc is the Chief Data Scientist at Wengo Analytics. When not innovating on data platforms, Finley enjoys spending time unicycling and playing with her pet iguana.

title: hi there!
text:
Hello everyone
I’m Matt!
I thought I’d start the switch from handwriting journals to something a little more versatile.
Think I might want to use this to share some out-of-work coding; perhaps also my thoughts on academia, data science, and miscellaneous life.

title: should affordable housing be for life?
bruneians by age and resident status
text:
Main libraries in code block.


show code
library(librarian)
shelf(readxl, tidyverse, reshape2)

title: bruneians by age and resident status
text:
population by age group
In the grand scheme of things, men outnumber women in Brunei by around 11.4%. What’s particularly interesting is the noticeable bulge in the 20-45 age range for men. In this subset, men outnumber women by an average of about 21.5%, compared to the overall difference per age group of around 4.6%.


show code
# total population by age group
age_group %>%
  filter(type == "total") %>% 
  # melt for male and female
  melt(value.name = "total",
       variable.name = "gender") %>%
  # plot
  ggplot(aes(fill = gender, 
             x = lower_age, 
             y = ifelse(
               test = gender == "male",
               # flip the values to the negative
               yes = -total,
               no = total),
             )) +
         geom_col(alpha = 0.9) +
  # flip the y-axis
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = abs, # set as absolute to remove negative sign
    limits = c(-25000, 25000) # set limits aesthetics
    ) +
  labs(
    x = "age group",
    y = "total",
    title = "population by age group"
  ) + # change color with brewer
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  theme_minimal()

title: bruneians by age and resident status
text:
age groups by nationality
This is where the real issue becomes clear. Our local population is relatively young, and it seems we are compensating for the shortage of young Bruneians with temporary residents.


show code
# total population by age group
age_group %>%
  #filter out total
  filter(type != "total") %>%
  # melt for male and female
  melt(
    value.name = "total",
    variable.name = "gender") %>%
  # plot
  ggplot(aes(fill = gender, 
             x = lower_age, 
             y = ifelse(
               test = gender == "male",
               # flip the values to the negative
               yes = -total,
               no = total),
             )) +
         geom_col(alpha = 0.9) +
  # flip the y-axis
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = abs, # set as absolute to remove negative sign
    # limits = c(-30000, 30000) # set limits aesthetics
    ) +
  labs(
    x = "age group",
    y = "total",
    title = "population by nationality"
  ) + # change color with brewer
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  facet_wrap(~type) +
  theme_minimal()









Temporary residents make up a significant proportion of the general population, constituting up to 34.4% across both genders. Among men aged 20 to 49, this percentage can reach as high as 40% in certain age groups.


show code
age_group %>% 
  filter(type != "total") %>%
  melt(value.name = "total",
       variable.name = "gender") %>% 
  # filter(age_group %in% c("20-24", "25-29", "30-34", "35-39", "40-44")) %>% 
  group_by(age_group, type) %>%
  summarise(total = sum(total)) %>% 
  # pivot wider
  pivot_wider(names_from = type, values_from = total) %>% 
  mutate(total = bruneian + permanent_resident + temporary_resident) %>% 
  # percentage of total
  mutate(
    bruneian = bruneian/total * 100,
    permanent_resident = permanent_resident/total * 100,
    temporary_resident = temporary_resident/total * 100) %>% 
  select(-total)


# A tibble: 18 × 4
# Groups:   age_group [18]
   age_group bruneian permanent_resident temporary_resident
   <chr>        <dbl>              <dbl>              <dbl>
 1 00-04         90.4               1.94               7.63
 2 05-09         89.6               2.07               8.37
 3 10-14         88.6               2.99               8.38
 4 15-19         89.1               4.10               6.76
 5 20-24         85.7               3.98              10.3 
 6 25-29         77.1               3.73              19.2 
 7 30-34         70.9               3.93              25.2 
 8 35-39         64.0               5.02              31.0 
 9 40-44         60.0               6.80              33.2 
10 45-49         57.9               7.65              34.4 
11 50-54         61.9               8.91              29.2 
12 55-59         69.3              11.2               19.5 
13 60-64         76.6              13.1               10.3 
14 65-69         79.7              14.0                6.29
15 70-74         81.3              13.9                4.78
16 75-79         80.7              14.8                4.51
17 80-84         80.5              15.5                4   
18 85+           78.7              18.0                3.28


Among men aged 20 to 49, this percentage can reach as high as 40% in certain age groups.


show code
age_group %>% 
  filter(type != "total") %>%
  melt(value.name = "total",
       variable.name = "gender") %>% 
  filter(age_group %in% c("20-24", 
                          "25-29", 
                          "30-34", 
                          "35-39", 
                          "40-44", 
                          "45-49")) %>% 
  group_by(age_group, type, gender) %>%
  filter(gender == "male") %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(total)) %>% 
  # pivot wider
  pivot_wider(names_from = type, values_from = total) %>% 
  mutate(total = bruneian + permanent_resident + temporary_resident) %>% 
  # percentage of total
  mutate(
    bruneian = bruneian/total * 100,
    permanent_resident = permanent_resident/total * 100,
    temporary_resident = temporary_resident/total * 100) %>% 
  select(-total)


# A tibble: 6 × 5
# Groups:   age_group [6]
  age_group gender bruneian permanent_resident temporary_resident
  <chr>     <fct>     <dbl>              <dbl>              <dbl>
1 20-24     male       83.3               3.89               12.8
2 25-29     male       71.4               3.44               25.1
3 30-34     male       65.3               3.72               31.0
4 35-39     male       58.0               3.97               38.0
5 40-44     male       55.6               4.89               39.5
6 45-49     male       54.2               5.67               40.1

title: bruneians by age and resident status
text:
per capita by nationality
Final pyramids show per capita of the age group and gender. It is the most telling of the nation’s overall population structure.
We can draw our own conclusions here on the implications on the Bruneian system.


show code
age_group %>% 
  filter(type != "total") %>% 
  group_by(type) %>% 
  mutate(total_m = sum(male),
         total_f = sum(female),
         `per capita male` = (male/total_m) * 100,
         `per capita female` = (female/total_f) * 100) %>% 
  select(lower_age, `per capita male`, `per capita female`) %>% 
  melt(variable.name = "gender",
       value.name = "total") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(fill = gender, 
             x = lower_age, 
             y = ifelse(
               test = gender == "per capita male",
               # flip the values to the negative
               yes = -total,
               no = total),
             )) +
         geom_col(alpha = 0.9) +
  # flip the y-axis
  coord_flip() +
  facet_wrap(~type) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = abs, # set as absolute to remove negative sign
    limits = c(-20, 20) # set limits aesthetics
    ) +
  labs(
    x = "total",
    y = "age group",
    title = "population by age group"
  ) + # change color with brewer
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  theme_minimal()

title: bruneians by age and resident status
text:
processing
The only real processing we need to do is to get the lower age limit for each of the age groups within the data set. That’s relatively simple with the following code:


show code
# read as age_group object
age_group <- read_xlsx("BN_age_group_nationality.xlsx")

# get first two characters from column
age_group <- age_group %>%
  mutate(lower_age = substr(age_group, 1, 2)) %>% 
  # reposition to second column
  relocate(lower_age, .before = age_group)

# final dataset
age_group


# A tibble: 72 × 5
   lower_age age_group type   male female
   <chr>     <chr>     <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>
 1 00        00-04     total 14258  13097
 2 05        05-09     total 16658  15276
 3 10        10-14     total 16051  15036
 4 15        15-19     total 17365  16425
 5 20        20-24     total 19870  17229
 6 25        25-29     total 22698  18408
 7 30        30-34     total 22630  17904
 8 35        35-39     total 21289  17136
 9 40        40-44     total 19231  16232
10 45        45-49     total 16463  15079
# ℹ 62 more rows

title: bruneians by age and resident status
section: per capita of gender by nationality
text:
per capita of gender by nationality
Final pyramids show per capita of the age group and gender. It is the most telling of the nation’s overall population structure.

Population pyramid suggests that we are still growing, at the beginning of stabilisation.

We can draw our own conclusions here on the implications on the Bruneian system.


show code
shelf(gganimate, png, gifski)

pop_pyr <- age_group %>% 
  filter(type != "total") %>% 
  mutate(total_m = sum(male),
         total_f = sum(female),
         `per capita m` = (male/total_m) *  100,
         `per capita f` = (female/total_f) *  100) %>%
  select(-male, -female, -total_m, -total_f) %>% 
  melt(variable.name = "gender",
       value.name = "total") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(fill = gender, 
             x = lower_age, 
             y = ifelse(
               test = gender == "per capita m",
               # flip the values to the negative
               yes = -total,
               no = total),
             )) +
  geom_col(alpha = 0.9) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = abs, # set as absolute to remove negative sign
    limits = c(-8, 8) # set limits aesthetics
    ) +
  labs(
    x = "age group",
    y = "% per capita",
    title = "% per capita by age group/nationality"
  )  + 
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  theme_minimal() + # animate
  transition_states(type, transition_length = 2, state_length = 1)
  
pop_pyr

title: bruneians by age and resident status
section: per capita of gender and nationality
text:
per capita of gender and nationality
The proportion of temporary residents in the 20-45 age group is pretty huge, with over 70% of them falling into this range.


show code
shelf(gganimate, png, gifski)

pop_pyr <- age_group %>% 
  filter(type != "total") %>% 
  group_by(type) %>%
  mutate(total_m = sum(male),
         total_f = sum(female),
         `per capita m` = (male/total_m) *  100,
         `per capita f` = (female/total_f) *  100) %>%
  select(-male, -female, -total_m, -total_f) %>% 
  melt(variable.name = "gender",
       value.name = "total") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(fill = gender, 
             x = lower_age, 
             y = ifelse(
               test = gender == "per capita m",
               # flip the values to the negative
               yes = -total,
               no = total),
             )) +
  geom_col(alpha = 0.9) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = abs, # set as absolute to remove negative sign
    limits = c(-18, 18) # set limits aesthetics
    ) +
  labs(
    x = "age group",
    y = "% per capita",
    title = "% per capita by age group/nationality"
  )  + 
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  theme_minimal() + # animate
  transition_states(type, transition_length = 2, state_length = 1)
  
pop_pyr









This big chunk of the population raises some interesting questions about what their presence means for us. The main question is whether we should let these temporary residents stay as permanent residents or even citizens to keep our population and workforce stable. If we need these workers long-term to support the economy, what are the effects of integrating them into our society? Are we ready to support their integration, and will they fit into the community in a way that feels right to Bruneians?
Also, since many of these temporary residents spend most of their prime working years in Brunei, should there be a way for them to become citizens since they’ve contributed to nation-building? How will our migration policies change, especially as our mostly young Bruneian population gets older and starts filling these age groups/labour roles?
Going back to the original question: why aren’t there more locals running their own businesses? Maybe Thomas was only seeing part of the picture. It’s tough to say since there are many factors at play. It seems to be a mix of having a young local population and a cultural aversion for front-facing or physical labor roles. It would be interesting to find out which parts of the workforce these temporary residents are in—especially the men. What industries are they in, and are they taking on roles that the local (predominantly male) workforce can’t handle?
